timeline.message:
Simple incomplete implementation for PrintFlagsFinal

A simple implementation of VM options that can be used to produce
the -XX:+PrintFlagsFinal output. I began separating out options
related code (very little of it at this point) into new files
runtime/oti/options.h, runtime/vm/options.inc, and
runtime/vm/options.c .

For now, I have only included two options in this new facility:
MaxHeapSize and MaxDirectMemorySize. These options are required
by the elasticsearch project, so I started with these. With this
facility implemented at OpenJ9, elasticsearch no longer NPEs on
startup and, in my local testing, all their tests pass on OpenJ9.

I tried to match, as closely as possible, the output Hotspot
generates when one uses -XX:+PrintFlagsFinal, which includes the
names used for types (e.g. size_t or uint64_t), the option names,
the option category (e.g. {product} or {diagnostic}), the way the
option is set (e.g. {default} or {ergonomic} or {command line}),
and the field sizes produced by a JDK11 Hotspot build. I did some
research online to find the set of types and such.

In options.c are found the main data structures that represent
the options. I build a static array with the list of options
and that array has a slot to hold the option's value. Since
OpenJ9's existing option handling code is distributed across
multiple components that all record options differently, I chose
to centralize the options for PrintFlagsFinal in this array which
means the option values need to be fetched from other spots to
fill in the array. That's not ideal. Going forward, I think we can
probably do better, but this is a starting point that works
reasonably well for simple options. By creating something independent
of the existing options framework, it's relatively easy to decide
if an option has been set on the command-line or not using the
standard `findArgInVMArgs()` service.

I don't think this framework represents an architectural direction;
I was just trying to put something relatively useful and reasonably
extensible in place that could hold us over until a more comprehensive
options framework rework (across components and probably across OMR
as well) can be undertaken.

Fixes: 7764

Signed-off-by: Mark Stoodley <mstoodle@ca.ibm.com>

timeline.message:
Simple incomplete implementation for PrintFlagsFinal

A simple implementation of VM options that can be used to produce
the -XX:+PrintFlagsFinal output. I began separating out options
related code (very little of it at this point) into new files
runtime/oti/options.h, runtime/vm/options.inc, and
runtime/vm/options.c .

For now, I have only included two options in this new facility:
MaxHeapSize and MaxDirectMemorySize. These options are required
by the elasticsearch project, so I started with these. With this
facility implemented at OpenJ9, elasticsearch no longer NPEs on
startup and, in my local testing, all their tests pass on OpenJ9.

I tried to match, as closely as possible, the output Hotspot
generates when one uses -XX:+PrintFlagsFinal, which includes the
names used for types (e.g. size_t or uint64_t), the option names,
the option category (e.g. {product} or {diagnostic}), the way the
option is set (e.g. {default} or {ergonomic} or {command line}),
and the field sizes produced by a JDK11 Hotspot build. I did some
research online to find the set of types and such.

In options.c are found the main data structures that represent
the options. I build a static array with the list of options
and that array has a slot to hold the option's value. Since
OpenJ9's existing option handling code is distributed across
multiple components that all record options differently, I chose
to centralize the options for PrintFlagsFinal in this array which
means the option values need to be fetched from other spots to
fill in the array. That's not ideal. Going forward, I think we can
probably do better, but this is a starting point that works
reasonably well for simple options. By creating something independent
of the existing options framework, it's relatively easy to decide
if an option has been set on the command-line or not using the
standard `findArgInVMArgs()` service. Setting the values is
performed via the function `initializeFlagSettings()`.

I don't think this framework represents an architectural direction;
I was just trying to put something relatively useful and reasonably
extensible in place that could hold us over until a more comprehensive
options framework rework (across components and probably across OMR
as well) can be undertaken.

Fixes: #7764

Signed-off-by: Mark Stoodley <mstoodle@ca.ibm.com>
